[Corion], [localtime://2011-08-28 07:57:45]
On a completely different note, I've been rummaging through the slow queries log and changing the SQL to not use functions on columns. This mostly consists of changing stuff like ... WHERE unix_timestamp(lasttime) > (unix_timestamp(now())-3600*24*7)

into

where lasttime>date_sub(now(), interval 7 day)

If a query uses a naked column, MySQL can use an index on that column. If we were using Pg, it could also be using an index on the function of a column, but we aren't.

It's unlikely that my changes have a vast effect, because the situations where I think adding a new index would really help are the situations where creating that index takes longer than the 10 seconds a query is allowed to run.

So far, I had to switch the version table back to memory anyway because MySQL decided that the table "got full". If we lost the current table values (due to a MySQL or memcached restart), the webservers would think they were out of date. But maybe that could be changed by having them not check whether the locally cached version is less than but instead checking whether the local version is identical and otherwise reloading. That way, a reset to version 0 would "only" be problematic when there are two restarts of the node server between accesses from the web server(s) to it, while other webservers changed the versions.

[tye], [localtime://2009-05-13 22:16:38]
I find "talk" quite a bit better than "chat" since the former is more clearly "make this text appear" and not "launch the 'chat' application".

"Send" is fine for [Message Outbox], though it is so vague that it could mean anything. Part of the reason we moved to more specific verbs was to reduce the frequency of people typing search terms into the chatterbox, etc. You can "Send" the keywords that you want to search on to the site. So "Send" can be seen as a synonym for "Submit" which is about as useful of a label as "Button" (if the user has used the web before).

"Deliver" would be less vague, but perhaps less accepted.

Note that I still don't see [bobf]'s point. The submit action should be a clear verb. The labels for the input fields should be clear. "To:" should probably be changed to note that a user's name is expected, actually. And I'd leave the submit button 3rd in the tab order for us dinosaurs that can navigate via a keyboard and like to push the button rather hit Enter in some random input field. I wonder if mouse-users would prefer the button directly under the input field (to reduce required sideways motion).

Perhaps better labels would be " Message:" and "For User:" (in isolation, "To User:" seems clearer, but perhaps not with "Message:"). At which point my first choice for button would still be "Tell". The minor contrast enforces that the purpose of the form is the intersection of the words present. I guess we could prepend "Send" so "To User:" seems natural:

Send
Message: [____________________________]
To User: [___________]
         [Deliver] (See also [Message Inbox])

Note that I've changed this wiki's boiler plate from "If you want to say something lengthy/complex, please post in [Inner Scriptorium]" to "If you want to have a discussion, please post in [Inner Scriptorium]". The latter more accurately covers what sucks about using a wiki, like what we are doing now.

My two cents...

Infrastructurally, private messaging and public chatting are not related; and anyway, they're pretty different modes of communication: chat is real-time interactive; [/msg]ing is like email. (Body-less email.)

IMHO, "talk" is fairly adequate for the cb, although it's essentially the same as "chat" — and the problem there is that "chatting" (or "talking") refers to one's ongoing involvement in the medium, vs. submitting a single line into the cb. A better word would be "say".

For private messaging, I think we can do no better than "send"; I believe that is what the vast majority of users think they are doing when they press that button.

Well those arent so weird actually. They are perfectly valid sql. Granted they arent beautiful, and i probably shouldnt have done that but anyway. The correct reformulation is to make the implicit joins be straight and not left. So SELECT ... FROM node baz, note bar LEFT JOIN htmlcode h ON h.htmlcode_id = baz.node_id WHERE baz.node_id = note.note_id Means, give me all the records from node and note where the node_id=note_id, (meaning dont show ones where either is NULL) and given me any corresponding htmlcode records that match as well, if they exist. Thus you want: SELECT ... FROM node baz JOIN note bar ON baz.node_id = note.note_id LEFT JOIN htmlcode h ON h.htmlcode_id = baz.node_id See http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/join.html, which as far as i can tell explains this issue as being one of a parser change to be more ANSI compliant.

Odds are high that this was my bad. A Sybase 11 side effect :-) My apologies.
